questionText: Increased precipitation from El Nino brings upsurges in diseases.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino may lessen global warming by temporarily stemming the release of carbon dioxide from the Pacific.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Private forecasting companies who sell predictions to businesses are pushing forecasting frontiers.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino usually occurs around December every 3-6 years.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: Global warming has been linked to El Nino.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: Sunspot activity has been linked to El Nino.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: El Nino causes reversals of normal weather patterns worldwide.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: El Nino typically lasts a year.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: La Nina reverses El Nino's effects.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: Predicting El Nino and its behavior is aided by computer modeling.
author: A3GWRDHAURRNK6

questionText: El Nino warming changes the winds and atmospheric pressure, shifting weather patterns and reducing carbon dioxide release.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: Increased water borne illnesses in Africa and decreased milk production in California have also been attributed to El Ninos.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: La Nina is the opposite condition from El Nino.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: El Nino is a periodic weather phenomenon caused by abnormal warming of the water in the eastern Pacific.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: This warming changes the winds and atmospheric pressure.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino can cause storms in California, tornadoes in Florida, a mild winter in the northern states.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino can cause storms and flooding in South America and Africa.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Scientists in the United States, Australia, Israel, and Germany are using sophisticated computer simulations.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Some Chinese are seeking links between El Nino and sunspot cycles.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Scientists around the world are trying to understand, track, and predict these phenomena.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: La Nina is the phenomenon of rapidly cooling equatorial waters in the central Pacific.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: La Nina works in reverse of El Nino.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: La Nina causes cooler conditions in central North America and dry warm conditions in the southern states.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: El Nino may also help cut global warming.
author: ANCCKNF1DKRZO

questionText: El Nino is a disruptive weather phenomenon.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino usually occurs every three to four years on the average.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino involves a surface warming of the eastern and central Pacific Ocean around the equator when trade winds weaken.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino can disrupt climate around the world.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino reverses normal weather patterns.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino helps trigger some man-made disasters, such as forest fires.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Computer module studies and satellite systems allow for a better understanding of how El Nino and La Nina form.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino can be credited with saving lives that would have been lost in normal winter and hurricane seasons.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: These phenomena even slow the Earth's rotation.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Scientific technologies and techniques for studying these phenomena include computer modeling.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Scientific technologies and techniques for studying these phenomena include simulation.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: Scientific technologies and techniques for studying these phenomena include onsite and remote satellite measurement of changes in weather data.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino and El Nina are opposite extremes of continuous but far ranging changes in precipitation.
author: AJQGWGESKQT4Y

questionText: El Nino and El Nina even slow the Earth's rotation
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: Slowing of the Earth's rotation has long-term global climate implications.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: Computer modeling a simulation are used to study El Nino and El Nina patterns.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science is one program used to study and predict El Nino and El Nina patterns.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: El Nino and El Nina result in dangerous temperature changes, storms, floods and droughts world wide.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C

questionText: The results of El Nino and El Nina can have severe economic impacts, disease and death.
author: A2IU5TX5S0FA1C
